elements.content: The hydrothermal reaction of Cr(NO3)3, Ln2O3, and iminodiacetate acid (H2IDA) in the molar ratio of 1:1:3 produced {[LnCr(IDA)2(C2O4)]} n (Ln = Eu, 1; Sm, 2), which represent the first 3D 3d−4f interpenetrating coordination polymers. In the reaction, the H2IDA ligands partly decompose into oxalate anions (ox), which connect LnIII ions to form 1D {Ln(ox)} n chains. Each of the CrIII ions is tridentate-coordinated by two IDA ligands, which act as tetradentate metalloligands to link {Ln(ox)} n chains to form 3D open networks. The two open networks interpenetrate each other to form nonporous products. 1 and 2 are thermally stable up to 327 and 360 °C, respectively. Both of complexes show normally paramagnetic behavior. The luminescent results imply that the energy transfers from LnIII to CrIII are strong.
elements.clean_text: The hydrothermal reaction of Cr(NO3)3, Ln2O3, and iminodiacetate acid (H2IDA) in the molar ratio of 1:1:3 produced {[LnCr(IDA)2(C2O4)]} n  (Ln = Eu, 1; Sm, 2), which represent the first 3D 3d-4f interpenetrating coordination polymers. In the reaction, the H2IDA ligands partly decompose into oxalate anions (ox), which connect LnIII ions to form 1D {Ln(ox)} n  chains. Each of the CrIII ions is tridentate-coordinated by two IDA ligands, which act as tetradentate metalloligands to link {Ln(ox)} n  chains to form 3D open networks. The two open networks interpenetrate each other to form nonporous products. 1 and 2 are thermally stable up to 327 and 360 °C, respectively. Both of complexes show normally paramagnetic behavior. The luminescent results imply that the energy transfers from LnIII to CrIII are strong.

elements.content: The first 3D Cr-containing heterometallic coordination polymers, two 2-fold interpenetrating 3d−4f compounds, were synthesized under hydrothermal conditions based on partial thermal decomposition of the organic ligand.
elements.clean_text: The first 3D Cr-containing heterometallic coordination polymers, two 2-fold interpenetrating 3d-4f compounds, were synthesized under hydrothermal conditions based on partial thermal decomposition of the organic ligand.

elements.content: The construction of three-dimensional (3D) coordination polymers has been a field of rapid growth in supramolecular and material chemistry because of the formation of fascinating structures and their potentially useful ion-exchange, adsorption, catalytic, fluorescence, and magnetic properties. Consequently, a variety of 3D metal−organic frameworks (MOFs) have been prepared through taking certain factors into account, such as the coordination nature of the metal ion, as well as the shape, functionality, flexibility, and symmetry of organic ligands. Multicarboxylate ligands are frequently chosen to construct a 3D MOF because of their rich coordination modes. For example, a series of carboxylate−zinc 3D MOFs with remarkable methane- and hydrogen-storage properties have been prepared by some groups. However, the syntheses of 3D MOFs have so far been exclusively centered on monometallic 3D coordination polymers, while the chemistry, as well as the synthetic strategy toward heterometallic coordination polymers, especially for these complexes containing rare-earth ions, has received much less attention because of the variable and versatile coordination behavior of 4f metal ions. For example, there are only a few examples for discrete molecules and even fewer examples for coordination polymers of LnIII−CrIII complexes.
elements.clean_text: The construction of three-dimensional (3D) coordination polymers has been a field of rapid growth in supramolecular and material chemistry because of the formation of fascinating structures and their potentially useful ion-exchange, adsorption, catalytic, fluorescence, and magnetic properties. Consequently, a variety of 3D metal-organic frameworks (MOFs) have been prepared through taking certain factors into account, such as the coordination nature of the metal ion, as well as the shape, functionality, flexibility, and symmetry of organic ligands. Multicarboxylate ligands are frequently chosen to construct a 3D MOF because of their rich coordination modes. For example, a series of carboxylate-zinc 3D MOFs with remarkable methane- and hydrogen-storage properties have been prepared by some groups. However, the syntheses of 3D MOFs have so far been exclusively centered on monometallic 3D coordination polymers, while the chemistry, as well as the synthetic strategy toward heterometallic coordination polymers, especially for these complexes containing rare-earth ions, has received much less attention because of the variable and versatile coordination behavior of 4f metal ions. For example, there are only a few examples for discrete molecules and even fewer examples for coordination polymers of LnIII-CrIII complexes.

elements.content: We have developed a series of 3D Ln−Mn zeolite-type nanoporous materials under hydrothermal conditions based on pyridine-2,6-dicarboxylic acid, and their luminescent properties were further investigated. Very recently, we reported the first 3D Pr−Ni−Na heterotrimetallic coordination polymer based on pyridine-2,4,6-tricarboxylic acid. While the multicarboxylate ligand iminodiacetate acid (H2IDA) was employed, we isolated two novel 3D 3d−4f coordination polymers {[LnCr(IDA)2(C2O4)]} n (Ln = Eu, 1; Sm, 2) under hydrothermal conditions, which were structurally characterized by X-ray single-crystal diffraction. Both 1 and 2 are 3D heterometallic interpenetrating structures, in which H2IDA ligands are found to partly break into oxalate anions (ox).
elements.clean_text: We have developed a series of 3D Ln-Mn zeolite-type nanoporous materials under hydrothermal conditions based on pyridine-2,6-dicarboxylic acid, and their luminescent properties were further investigated. Very recently, we  reported the first 3D Pr-Ni-Na heterotrimetallic coordination polymer based on pyridine-2,4,6-tricarboxylic acid. While the multicarboxylate ligand iminodiacetate acid (H2IDA) was employed, we isolated two novel 3D 3d-4f coordination polymers {[LnCr(IDA)2(C2O4)]} n  (Ln = Eu, 1; Sm, 2) under hydrothermal conditions, which were structurally characterized by X-ray single-crystal diffraction. Both 1 and 2 are 3D heterometallic interpenetrating structures, in which H2IDA ligands are found to partly break into oxalate anions (ox).

elements.content: Once formed, the title compounds are stable in air and insoluble in water or in common organic solvents. In the reactions, part of the H2IDA molecules thermally decompose into ox ligands and others coordinate with CrIII ions (Scheme ). The ox ligands link LnIII ions to form one-dimensional (1D) {Ln(ox)} n chains. The stability of the product and its insolubility in the reaction medium are mostly responsible for the breakage of the ligand and drive the reaction forward.
elements.clean_text: Once formed, the title compounds are stable in air and insoluble in water or in common organic solvents. In the reactions, part of the H2IDA molecules thermally decompose into ox ligands and others coordinate with CrIII ions (Scheme ). The ox ligands link LnIII ions to form one-dimensional (1D) {Ln(ox)} n  chains. The stability of the product and its insolubility in the reaction medium are mostly responsible for the breakage of the ligand and drive the reaction forward.

elements.content: The single-crystal analysis reveals that 1 and 2 are isomorphous. In 1, the CrIII ion is chelated by two IDA ligands to form a tetradentate metalloligand, with each of the uncoordinated O atoms coordinating to a EuIII ion. Each EuIII ion is bidentately chelated by two ox ligands. As a result, each CrIII ion is six-coordinated in a distorted octahedral geometry by four O atoms and two N atoms, while each EuIII ion is eight-coordinated through interactions with carboxylate groups from four metalloligands and from two ox ligands (Figure S1 in the Supporting Information). The bond lengths of Cr−N, Cr−O, and Eu−O are 2.049, 1.978, and 2.376−2.419 Å, respectively. The ox ligands link EuIII ions to form {Ln(ox)} n chains, which are further connected with the metalloligands to form one of two interpenetrating 3D networks (Figure ). The shortest Cr···Cr, Cr···Eu, and Eu···Eu separations in 1 are 10.799, 6.240, and 6.255 Å, respectively. Therefore, the 3D network exhibits 1D channels along the c direction with a dimensionality of 10.8 × 10.8 Å2 (defined by the separation between the two nearest LnIII ions). To our knowledge, this is the first CrIII-containing heterometallic 3D coordination polymer.
elements.clean_text: The single-crystal analysis reveals that 1 and 2 are isomorphous. In 1, the CrIII ion is chelated by two IDA ligands to form a tetradentate metalloligand, with each of the uncoordinated O atoms coordinating to a EuIII ion. Each EuIII ion is bidentately chelated by two ox ligands. As a result, each CrIII ion is six-coordinated in a distorted octahedral geometry by four O atoms and two N atoms, while each EuIII ion is eight-coordinated through interactions with carboxylate groups from four metalloligands and from two ox ligands (Figure S1 in the Supporting Information). The bond lengths of Cr-N, Cr-O, and Eu-O are 2.049, 1.978, and 2.376-2.419 Å, respectively. The ox ligands link EuIII ions to form {Ln(ox)} n  chains, which are further connected with the metalloligands to form one of two interpenetrating 3D networks (Figure ). The shortest Cr⋅⋅⋅Cr, Cr⋅⋅⋅Eu, and Eu⋅⋅⋅Eu separations in 1 are 10.799, 6.240, and 6.255 Å, respectively. Therefore, the 3D network exhibits 1D channels along the c direction with a dimensionality of 10.8 × 10.8 Å2 (defined by the separation between the two nearest LnIII ions). To our knowledge, this is the first CrIII-containing heterometallic 3D coordination polymer.

elements.content: One of two interpenetrating 3D networks along thec direction. Color code:  purple, Cr; green, Ln.
elements.clean_text: 1  One of two interpenetrating 3D networks along thec direction. Color code: purple, Cr; green, Ln.

elements.content: It is interesting to note that two 3D networks are interpenetrated, which results into a nonporous crystal product (Figure ). Viewing along the c direction, each {Ln(ox)} n chain in one 3D network occupies the 1D channel of another network, while each Cr center alternatively arranges for two different networks. From a topological view, each Cr and Ln center can be considered as four- and six-connected nodes, respectively. The first 3D 3d−4f interpenetrating topology is shown in Figure .
elements.clean_text: It is interesting to note that two 3D networks are interpenetrated, which results into a nonporous crystal product (Figure ). Viewing along the c direction, each {Ln(ox)} n  chain in one 3D network occupies the 1D channel of another network, while each Cr center alternatively arranges for two different networks. From a topological view, each Cr and Ln center can be considered as four- and six-connected nodes, respectively. The first 3D 3d-4f interpenetrating topology is shown in Figure .

elements.content: Space-filling view shows the open channel (left) and 2-fold interpenetrating networks (right) along thec direction.
elements.clean_text: 2  Space-filling view shows the open channel (left) and 2-fold interpenetrating networks (right) along thec direction.

elements.content: Color code:  purple, Ln; cyan, Cr; yellow and green lines, connectivity between metal centers by bridged organic ligands.
elements.clean_text: 3  Color code: purple, Ln; cyan, Cr; yellow and green lines, connectivity between metal centers by bridged organic ligands.

elements.content: The phase purities of the bulk materials of 1 and 2 were confirmed by a comparison of their powder diffraction patterns with those calculated from the single-crystal study. Thermogravimetric analyses of the polycrystalline samples of 1 and 2 were performed in the temperature range 25−800 °C (Figure S2 in the Supporting Information). Both compounds showed high thermal stability, and the first weight loss began at 327 and 360 °C for 1 and 2, respectively. Decomposition of the organic ligand took place up to 530 °C. After being heated to 800 °C in air, both solids were converted to black powders.
elements.clean_text: The phase purities of the bulk materials of 1 and 2 were confirmed by a comparison of their powder diffraction patterns with those calculated from the single-crystal study. Thermogravimetric analyses of the polycrystalline samples of 1 and 2 were performed in the temperature range 25-800 °C (Figure S2 in the Supporting Information). Both  compounds showed high thermal stability, and the first weight loss began at 327 and 360 °C for 1 and 2, respectively. Decomposition of the organic ligand took place up to 530 °C. After being heated to 800 °C in air, both solids were converted to black powders.

elements.content: Informative magnetic susceptibility measurements of 1 and 2 have been performed on a Quantum Design MPMS-5S superconducting quantum interference device (SQUID) magnetometer in the 4−300 K temperature range, with an applied field of 1000 Oe. The diamagnetic correction was evaluated by using Pascal's constants. As shown in Figure , the χM T value is equal to 3.41 cm3 K mol-1 at room temperature. The magnetic susceptibility of EuIII is expected to be zero in view of the ground state 7F0, but the observed χM T value of 1 is larger than the CrIII-only value. This is due to the fact that a certain amount of the magnetic moment is contributed from the excited states 7F1 and 7F2. The χM T values for 1 decrease with decreasing temperature, which attributes to the thermal depopulation of these excited levels. At 4 K, the χM T value is 1.73 cm3 K mol-1, which is close to the expected CrIII-only value, ca. 1.8 cm3 K mol-1 at 4 K.
elements.clean_text: Informative magnetic susceptibility measurements of 1 and 2 have been performed on a Quantum Design MPMS-5S superconducting quantum interference device (SQUID) magnetometer in the 4-300 K temperature range, with an applied field of 1000 Oe. The diamagnetic correction was evaluated by using Pascal's constants. As shown in Figure , the χM T value is equal to 3.41 cm3 K mol-1 at room temperature. The magnetic susceptibility of EuIII is expected to be zero in view of the ground state 7F0, but the observed χM T value of 1 is larger than the CrIII-only value. This is due to the fact that a certain amount of the magnetic moment is contributed from the excited states 7F1 and 7F2. The χM T values for 1 decrease with decreasing temperature, which attributes to the thermal depopulation of these excited levels. At 4 K, the χM T value is 1.73 cm3 K mol-1, which is close to the expected CrIII-only value, ca. 1.8 cm3 K mol-1 at 4K.

elements.content: Thermal dependence of the χM T and χM -1 curves:  1 (□); 2 (◇, ▵).
elements.clean_text: 4  Thermal dependence of the χM T and χM -1 curves: 1 (□); 2 (◇, ▵).

elements.content: For complex 2, the observed χM T value at 300 K is 2.19 cm3 mol-1 K, higher than the calculated value of 1.96 cm3 mol-1 K for one free CrIII ion and one isolated SmIII ion with a ground state of 6H5/2. This may be due to the nonnegligible population of excited states such as 6H7/2 of the SmIII ion. Upon cooling, the χM T slightly decreases and reaches 1.85 cm3 mol-1 K at 4 K. The linear fit via χM = C/(T − θ) reveals a Curie−Weiss behavior over 4−300 K with C = 2.16 cm3 mol-1 K and θ = −4.03 K. The depopulation of SmIII ions from excited states, antiferromagnetic interactions between the neighboring paramagnetic centers, and/or the expected effect from a zero-field splitting of the CrIII ions may influence the magnetic behavior in this way.
elements.clean_text: For complex 2, the observed χM T value at 300 K is 2.19 cm3 mol-1 K, higher than the calculated value of 1.96 cm3 mol-1 K for one free CrIII ion and one isolated SmIII ion with a ground state of 6H5/2. This may be due to the nonnegligible population of excited states such as 6H7/2 of the SmIII ion. Upon cooling, the χM T slightly decreases and reaches 1.85 cm3 mol-1 K at 4 K. The linear fit via χM = C/(T - θ) reveals a Curie-Weiss behavior over 4-300 K with C = 2.16 cm3 mol-1 K and θ = -4.03 K. The depopulation of SmIII ions from excited states, antiferromagnetic interactions between the neighboring paramagnetic centers, and/or the expected effect from a zero-field splitting of the CrIII ions may influence the magnetic behavior in this way.

elements.content: Generally, EuIII and SmIII complexes exhibit a characteristic sharp luminescence. However, the microcrystalline samples of 1 and 2 did not show obvious sharply characterized emission bands at room temperature. Because the ligand field absorption band envelope for the CrIII chromophore overlaps with the spectral range of the narrow emissions of EuIII and SmIII, the efficient quenching occurs in the LnIII luminescence, resulting from the resonance between the LnIII excited levels and the broad ligand-field state of the CrIII ion (Figure S3 in the Supporting Information). Therefore, the maximum emission peaks at 733 nm of 1 and 2 can be attributed to 2E → 4A2 of the CrIII ions. The peak positions and relative intensities are a little different between 1 and 2. This quenching behavior is compared with that of other Ln−Cr complexes, which implies that energy transfer from LnIII to CrIII is highly effective.
elements.clean_text: Generally, EuIII and SmIII complexes exhibit a characteristic sharp luminescence. However, the microcrystalline samples of 1 and 2 did not show obvious sharply characterized emission bands at room temperature. Because the ligand field absorption band envelope for the CrIII chromophore overlaps with the spectral range of the narrow emissions of EuIII and SmIII, the efficient quenching occurs in the LnIII luminescence, resulting from the resonance between the LnIII excited levels and the broad ligand-field state of the CrIII ion (Figure S3 in the Supporting Information). Therefore, the maximum emission peaks at 733 nm of 1 and 2 can be attributed to 2E → 4A2 of the CrIII ions. The peak positions and relative intensities are a little different between 1 and 2. This quenching behavior is compared with that of other Ln-Cr complexes, which implies that energy transfer from LnIII to CrIII is highly effective.

elements.content: In summary, the first 3D Cr-containing heterometallic coordination polymers were synthesized. The H2IDA ligands were found to partly break into ox ligands in the reaction, which connect LnIII ions to form 1D {Ln(ox)} n chains. Two 3D open networks interpenetrate each other to form the first 3D 3d−4f interpenetrating structure. The CrIII−LnIII interactions in the compounds are very weak in magnetic interactions but are strong from the viewpoint of energy transfer. The systematic and detailed investigation of magnetic and luminescent properties of Ln−Cr 3D coordination polymers is currently underway.
elements.clean_text: In summary, the first 3D Cr-containing heterometallic coordination polymers were synthesized. The H2IDA ligands were found to partly break into ox ligands in the reaction, which connect LnIII ions to form 1D {Ln(ox)} n  chains. Two 3D open networks interpenetrate each other to form the first 3D 3d-4f interpenetrating structure. The CrIII-LnIII interactions in the compounds are very weak in magnetic interactions but are strong from the viewpoint of energy transfer. The systematic and detailed investigation of magnetic and luminescent properties of Ln-Cr 3D coordination polymers is currently underway.
